Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: Got pulled away earlier.  I got into it with someone on Reddit a while back saying how KMD has awesome tech and will be revolutionary and how if I only fully understood the project I would know it was the Future (capital F).  Great, I want to believe that since I own some.  But as I expressed my concerns, he let it slip that he only owned $100 worth.  Hah.  Thinking back on that exchange, it doesn't mean anything to me if a grown adult tells me something is going to change the world but he only owns $100 of it (while its on sale!!).  So my question for Siu (and if you wanna get in on this, Hollow), how much KMD do you own?  You know the project in and out, you are balls deep in its tech, you have supreme faith in JLGTQ777 and the team.... how much skin do you have in the game?

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: Fine to just observe.  I personally have never heard from anyone who claims to own more than a couple hundred bucks worth.  djithbit is the highest claim I have yet to hear.  But it seems to always be the people who own very little that are the biggest evangelists.   I know most people go through life never putting their money where there mouth is, but I would certainly have more respect for people's technical praises of KMD and their absolute belief in its success if they responded with, "I was in on the ICO, I have been dollar cost average buying for months, I mine it on my home computer and when I get my paycheck at the end of this month, I am buying another 500 KMD to get me up to my target of 100,000 KMD.  I have resisted urges to dine out and to vacation so I can pack every extra dollar into this investment that I am so passionate and sure of."  I have yet to hear that response...

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: @xRobeSx  I may poke my head around a little, but there are people like y'all in every subreddit and discord channel for every coin in the top 100, be it a decent project or a shit coin--people who are true believer whales in projects that statistically will not survive.  What I, as an investor/speculator want to see is Komodo make good on some of what it needs to improve.  I am tired of hearing about how awesome it "will" be and I want to see a wallet with a good GUI, logical text strings and have it be more exciting to look at than a pile of potatoes.  I want to see a marketing team that can convince other projects that BTC notary is needed.  Frankly I want to  see any marketing at all.  I tried to mess with Barterdex for that Beer swap and it was essentially alpha testing without any clear idea of why or to what end.  These are reasonable things to want.

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: @KomodoWorld KMD evangelists always talk about this background tech and make the claim that it is so robust.  But I am not a tech guy, so how can I refute that?  But I get the feeling that KMD fans are basically like 1)it is a smart contract platform like ETH... but BETTER!  2) It is a secure value of transfer mechanism like BTC... but BETTER!  3) It can be anonymous like Monero... but BETTER!   So its like all other top projects but better and then they just tell me I need to better understand the tech and back end.  That isn't an argument, though.  It is a deflection.

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: I am not a newcommer to blockchain.  But it is hard for me to wrap my mind around lots of aspects of it.  The more obscure functionalities of ETH, for instance, make me dizzy when I try to understand them.  But I tend to get skeptical when the #63 market cap coin claims to do what coins #1 #2 and #14 do, but better... while (drum roll) also being more decentralized!

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: And frankly, I am much more tech savvy than most.  I build my own computers, swap out components, I have ghosted machines and installed foreign operating systems, worked at software companies, etc.  So like 90% of the public cant possibly understand what everyone claims is so great about KMD

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Here is how it's more decentralized:  Komodo has 64 nodes that do 75% of the mining.  Pools and solo miners account for the rest.  For simplicity sake I'll just call it 100.  Compare that to the percentage of hashrate that the major pools on btc eth ltc etc.  have  and you have less than a dozen controlling 90%+ of a coin

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: KMD needs a marketing team that can explain what KMD does in a way that is engaging and can be understood by the average college graduate.  Not some hodge podge of crypto catch phrases and promises based on unexplained tech.

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: And ETH got there first, it is furthest ahead, it has first mover advantage in the smart contract space.  It will attract more developers, more corporations, etc.  It won't be dethroned for years.

Content: first mover advantage doesn't matter if at the end it can't do the job properly
